awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Trustworthy Composition of Dynamic App-Centric Architectures for Medical Application Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to achieve key technology, infrastructure, and
regulatory science advances for next generation medical systems based
on the concept of medical application platforms (MAPs). A MAP is a
safety/security-critical real-time computing platform for: (a)
integrating heterogeneous devices and medical IT systems, (b) hosting
application programs ("apps") that provide medical utility through the
ability to both acquire information and update/control integrated
devices, IT systems, and displays. The project will develop formal
architectural and behavioral specification languages for defining
MAPs, with a focus on techniques that enable compositional reasoning
about MAP component interoperability and safety. These formal
languages will include an extensible property language to enable the
specification of real-time, quality-of-service, and attributes
specific to medical contexts that can be leveraged by code generation,
testing, and verification tools.

The project will work closely with a synergistic team of clinicians,
device industry partners, regulators, and medical device
interoperability and safety standard organizations to develop an open
source MAP innovation platform to enable key stakeholders within the
nation's health care ecosphere to identify, prototype, and evaluate
solutions to key technology and regulatory challenges that must be
overcome to develop a commodity market of regulated MAP components.
Because MAPs provide pre-built certified infrastructure and building
blocks for rapidly developing multi-device medical applications, this
research has the potential to usher in a new paradigm of medical
system that significantly increases the pace of innovation, lowers
development costs, enables new functionality by aggregating multiple
devices into a system of systems, and achieves greater system safety.

por.por_cntn:
Medical devices historically have been developed as stand-alone units. Current industrial Verification and Validation (V&V) techniques are oriented for stand-alone systems. Moreover, the US Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) regulatory clearance processes most naturally support devices that are integrated by a single manufacturer.   However, from a systems engineering perspective, it is well understood that the current state of medical practice uses devices and health in-formation systems (HIS) cooperatively following informal manual protocols to?deliver clinical solutions.

This project focused on providing computing and networking infrastructure, a safety/security framework, and trustworthy composition techniques to integrate medical devices and HIS, and to automatically coordinate their actions as a system of systems (SoS).  A key outcome of this project was the development of foundational concepts of Medical Application Platforms (MAP).   MAPs support an emerging vision that would provide device and HIS interoperability, safety critical network middleware, and an execution environment for clinical applications (“apps”) that encode the envisioned medical SoS behaviors including multi-device smart alarms, safety interlocks, enhanced clinical decision support, automated clinical workflows, and closed loop control applications.

Working with a synergistic and multi-disciplinary team of academic researchers, clinicians, device manufacturers, device integrators, health IT companies, regulatory agencies, standards/certification organizations, this project developed a MAP prototype called the Medical Device Coordination Framework (MDCF) to support a broad-based community effort in this domain.  Moreover, the prototype was seeded with key technological advances in areas that were deemed to be especially important for realizing the vision of safe and effective medical application platforms.  Many of the research efforts targeted the Integrated Clinical Environment (ICE) architecture – a particular architecture for MAP standardized by ASTM.  The project made the following specific contributions:

*  Key architectural and systems engineering principles central to the MAP concept were documented and disseminated within the research, industry, and regulatory communities.

* Open-source communication and app-hosting infrastructure was developed that utilized middeware technology proven in use in other critical domains.

* Novel extensions were made to the middleware that utilized Google’s OpenFlow network switch technology to enforce real-time constraints and protections on communication.  This ensures that communication between apps and medical devices is achieved in timely manner and that communication associated with one app cannot interfere with that of another simultaneously executing app.

* A medical app development environment was constructed to illustrate full life-cycle development activities leading to the types of artifacts that would need to be submitted for regulatory approval of apps.  The environment demonstrated how integrated development, verification, and certification tools MAP apps could be developed based on industry standard modeling languages, development processes, and safety standards.

* Evidence-based V&V techniques, compositional contract-based approaches for reasoning about key functional and non- functional properties, e.g., timeliness, reliability, end-to-end communication latency were developed.

* The project prototyped device technology for futuristic medical devices that can be deeply integrated with MAPs, allowing them to have significantly altered form-factors, to be reconfigurable, and adaptive, and to support easy care-context migration of patients.

* Working with collaborators at the US FDA and at Underwriters Laboratories, the project defined and illustrated evidence-based safety-ecosphere concepts for MAP systems including 3rd party certification guidelines, tools, and example artifacts, along with descriptions and examples of how regulatory oversight of MAP systems might be handled.

The broader impacts of this work were far-reaching

* Based on the research results and impact of this project, the project PI, Dr. John Hatcliff, was invited to co-chair the primary working group of the AAMI/UL 2800 committee working on a family of safety and security standards for interoperable medical systems.  Many of the principles developed in the project research are being incorporated into the standard framework.   Dr. Eugene Vasserman, a co-PI on the project, was invited to lead the security working group of the 2800 standard.

* The project team worked closely with FDA engineers on research papers and regulatory concepts related to MAPs.  Supported in part by the NSF FDA Scholar-in-Residence program, the team worked with FDA engineers to develop open-source medical device development artifacts, risk management, and assurance approaches to support the MAP vision.  Based on his activities in medical device security, co-PI Vasserman is now doing a sabbatical at the FDA.

* Results from the project flowed into a large-scale NIH/NIBIB research project lead by Dr. Julian Goldman from Massachusetts General Hospital.   Collaboration with Dr. Goldman’s team enabled validation of a number of important technology concepts in realistic clinical scenarios.

* The project spawned multiple industry technology transfer efforts with additional funding coming from the Department of Homeland Security’s Cyber-Physical System’s Security Program (CPSSEC) and a DoD SBIR Phase I and II awards.  Outcomes from the project related to open-source artifacts for an ICE-enabled Patient-Controlled Analgesic Pump formed the basis of a DHS CPSSEC award with Adventium Labs to develop a high-assurance reusable medical device infrastructure.
